case_title: INDU BHUSHAN SAH (H.U.F.) vs WEALTH TAX OFFICER and another
complaint_summary: The appellant challenged the initiation of assessment proceedings under Section 17 of the Wealth Tax Act for the assessment years 1975-76 to 1978-79, alleging that the notices were issued solely based on audit objections.
investigation_summary: The appellant inspected the files on July 24, 1981, revealing that the impugned notices were issued due to audit objections. No counter-affidavit was filed by the respondents despite repeated opportunities over 13 years.
judgment_summary: The writ petitions were allowed with costs, and the impugned notices and orders were quashed as they were based solely on audit objections, which cannot justify reopening of assessments.
Decision_or_verdict: Impugned notices and orders quashed; writ petitions allowed with costs.
legal_arguments: Section 17 of the Wealth Tax Act is in pari materia with Section 147 of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

Audit objections cannot form the basis for reopening assessments as per precedents in Ashoke Gupta v. Asstt. CED (1991) 188 ITR 715 (All.) and Indian and Eastern Newspaper Society Ltd. (1979) 119 ITR 996 (SC).
sections: Section 17 of the Wealth Tax Act
Section 35 of the Wealth Tax Act
Section 16-A(2) of the Wealth Tax Act
Section 147 of the Income Tax Act
Section 59 of the Estate Duty Act
citations: Ashoke Gupta v. Asstt. CED (1991) 188 ITR 715 (All.)
Indian and Eastern Newspaper Society Ltd. (1979) 119 ITR 996 (SC)
key_issues: Validity of assessment proceedings initiated under Section 17 of the Wealth Tax Act based on audit objections.
Applicability of precedents regarding reopening assessments.
key_points: Two writ petitions were disposed of through a common judgment.
No counter-affidavit was filed by the Revenue despite multiple opportunities over 13 years.
Petitioner sought quashing of assessment proceedings initiated under Section 17 of the Wealth Tax Act for various assessment years.
Impugned notices were issued based on audit objections, which were deemed insufficient grounds for reopening assessments.
Judgment relied on precedents including Ashoke Gupta v. Asstt. CED (1991) 188 ITR 715 (All.) and Indian and Eastern Newspaper Society Ltd. (1979) 119 ITR 996 (SC).
Impugned notices and orders were declared illegal and quashed.

maxims.pari materia: Statutes addressing similar subject matter should be interpreted harmoniously.

legal_terms.audit objection: A formal objection raised during the audit process regarding procedural or substantive issues.

words_and_phrases.impugned notice: A notice that is being challenged in a legal proceeding.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves the challenge to assessment proceedings under Section 17 of the Wealth Tax Act for multiple years. The court quashed the notices and orders, citing precedents that audit objections cannot justify reopening assessments.
